文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_019_chunk1
证据片段: Nodular corrosion data of Zircaloys in water reactor environments are reviewed to show that in addition to variables such as temperature, water chemistry, material, and irradiation flux, heat flux is an important variable.

文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_019_chunk1
证据片段: Qualitative evidence that suggests increased nodular oxidation rate with increasing heat flux at low heat fluxes and a reverse dependence at high heat fluxes where boiling occurs is presented.

文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_019_chunk1
证据片段: In-pile nodular accelerated corrosion (NAC) occurs only in oxygenated conditions at typical LWR conditions (70 to 150 bar and 250 to 320°C)

文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_019_chunk1
证据片段: In-pile nodular accelerated corrosion (NAC) occurs only in oxygenated conditions at typical LWR conditions (70 to 150 bar and 250 to 320°C)

文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_019_chunk1
证据片段: Under oxygenated conditions, which is the case for today's boiling water reactors (BWRs) with ~200 ppb O₂ (PWRs typically have ≲5 ppb O₂)

文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_019_chunk1
证据片段: The NAC rate has been associated with material microstructure, composition, and surface condition; and with the environmental variables of O₂, H₂, impurity concentrations in the coolant, heat flux, and flow conditions

文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_019_chunk1
证据片段: Several observations of Zircaloy corrosion in BWRs have revealed a significant difference in the corrosion rate between low-heat-flux (LHF) and high-heat-flux (HHF) components

文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_019_chunk1
证据片段: the corrosion rate, or at least the nodular-corrosion rate, is often larger in LHF components

文献ID: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_019_chunk1
证据片段: the boiling at the rod surface in HHF regions removes O₂ and the aggressive radiolytically produced radicals from the Zircaloy surface
